title: Are tabloids to be trusted? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: I use Media Bias/Fact Check on a regular basis to determine the credibility of a source. Here is what they say about the Daily Mail:    QUESTIONABLE SOURCE A questionable source exhibits one or more of the following: extreme bias, consistent promotion of propaganda/conspiracies, poor or no sourcing to credible information, a complete lack of transparency and/or is fake news. Fake News is the deliberate attempt to publish hoaxes and/or disinformation for the purpose of profit or influence (Learn More). Sources listed in the Questionable Category may be very untrustworthy and should be fact checked on a per article basis. Please note sources on this list are not considered fake news unless specifically written in the reasoning section for that source. See all Questionable sources. They may utilize strong loaded words (wording that attempts to influence an audience by using appeal to emotion or stereotypes), publish misleading reports and omit reporting of information that may damage conservative causes. Some sources in this category may be untrustworthy. See all Right Bias sources. Overall, we rate The Sun Right Biased based on story selection and political affiliation that favors the right. No. Never take anything in a tabloid at face value. I wrote a book about my experience with the tabloids. In 2014, I was dragged into a $10,000,000 lawsuit between two men. It was a breach of contract lawsuit that claimed that the defendant had poached the Plaintiff’s keyboard player and had stolen the Plaintiff’s idea to start Long Island’s first P!NK Cover Band. The split happened when the defendant had been investigated for elder fraud by Chase Bank. I was named as an accomplice in the lawsuit (not the elder fraud, just the whole “stealing his idea part”). I spoke to a journalist at The New York Post for a couple of days. They extensively covered the relationship between the two men when interviewing me. They asked me about the elder fraud investigation and why the two men were fighting. It was an exhaustive interview process that lasted two days. Here is the headline they came up with: Singer sued for being too old and ugly for Pink cover band They had a perfectly good TRUE story they could have told, but went with this mostly made up story (that took actual text from the lawsuit and spun it). Some of the quotes from me in the article are made up from thin air! This story was told on the news, on the radio and at tabloids around the world. It wasn’t true. Don’t. Trust. Tabloids.

While I hate to generalize, the vast majority of tabloids since their inception have been about attracting readers by making use of scandal and sensationalism. And while it is true that some tabloids have also had a few good reporters, that’s not what these publications are usually known for. So, if you are reading the tabloids, just be aware that although what you see might be entertaining, it might also be exaggerated, or sensationalized, or biased; and also be aware that the writers may have gotten the information by paying for it (a practice called “checkbook journalism,” widely regarded by most mainstream publications as unethical).

Some are. Some aren’t. A tabloid is any newspaper that’s half the size of a broadsheet. The size of the page has nothing to do with its credibility. Some tabloids are highly sensational, but still highly credible, such as the Philadelphia Daily News during its heyday when it was winning Pulitzer Prizes. Others aren’t sensational at all, such as the Christian Science Monitor. And some are just a bunch of nonsense.
